Quoth Scott Stirling:
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Craig Dickson [mailto:craigsdickson@...] 
> > 
> > I would definately be interested in an extension to
> > the JUnit batchtest task in Ant that could gather the
> > tests that had been compiled in the last "x" minutes,
> > or even better gather the tests that relate to classes
> > (perhaps via naming patterns) that have been compiled
> > in the last "x" minutes.
> 
> This might be do-able in Ant with a combo of <uptodate/> task and the
> <junit><batchtest/> task.  [...]
  [...]

I was thinking much the same thing, but unless there's something
I'm missing in Ant (certainly possible), this technique is too
cumbersome for fine-grained incremental testing.

Suppose, for concreteness, that I have a test class FooTests,
which tests a class Foo.  I want FooTests to run only if either
FooTests.java or Foo.java has changed since the last time it was
run, so I write (1) a target which uses <junit> to run FooTests
and touches a timestamp file to record when the test was run, and
(2) a target which uses <uptodate> to compare the timestamps of
the timestamp file and the sources, setting a property
FooTest.do-run-run if the sources have changed.  Target 1 depends
on target 2 and has attribute if='FooTest.do-run-run'.

All good so far.

The next day, I write some more classes Foo1, Foo2, ..., Foo46,
and their tests Foo1Test, Foo2Test, ..., Foo46Test.  (I was on
vacation in Minsk the day of that seminar on naming classes
meaningfully.)

I want each test to run only if it or its corresponding source
file has changed, so... I add <uptodate> and <junit> targets for
each of the forty-six new classes, each pair controlling its
behaviour with a FooNTest.do-run-run property.  That's ninety-four
targets altogether.

Either of the following additions to Ant would make it possible to
state the desired behaviour tersely:

1. A version of <fileset> which lets us say "omit from the set
those files which are newer than their corresponding file under
this <mapper>".  (Properly done, this involves implementing a
fairly general algebra on sets of file names.)

2. A looping construction, that is, a way to say "for every file x
in this <fileset>, execute task y with property z set to 'x'". 
(In the case at hand, the task would be an <antcall> to the
<junit> task.)

On reflection, it seems a bit odd that these kinds of facilities
aren't already in Ant.  Am I missing something?
